rationales.self_direction: Layla chose to stay horizontal on the beach rather than go paddleboarding, making her own decision about what she needed despite her friend's suggestion.
rationales.hedonism: She spent the entire afternoon at Kite Beach soaking in the sun, savoring the sound of waves, and relishing not thinking about the hospital for hours.
rationales.benevolence: She spent her day off with her close friends Nadia and Sara, prioritizing quality time with the people she cares about.

rationales.hedonism: She ate three servings of kashk-e bademjan with crispy tahdig at a new Persian restaurant, describing the food with relish and her stomach hurting 'in the best way possible.'
rationales.benevolence: The evening was spent enjoying the meal with Nadia, valuing the experience of good food and good company with close friends.

rationales.self_direction: Layla wants to rest without having to justify her choices to anyone, asserting her right to live on her own terms away from family pressure.
rationales.conformity: She resists the family gatherings where everyone asks about marriage and judges her for 'wasting her best years,' refusing to conform to their expectations.
rationales.tradition: She avoids visiting Beirut and the traditional family gatherings, pushing back against the cultural script of marriage and settling down.
rationales.benevolence: She spent most of her shift holding the hand of a child's mother in the oncology ward while doctors explained treatment options.

rationales.self_direction: Layla defends her right to take care of herself against Fatima's judgment, refusing to accept that not working extra shifts makes her less committed.
rationales.hedonism: She explicitly frames self-care and enjoyment as essential, not optional, grounded in her father's heart attack as proof that sacrificing pleasure for work is destructive.
rationales.security: She made a deliberate life decision at nineteen — watching her father in the hospital — to protect herself from the same fate, building a boundary around her wellbeing.
rationales.conformity: She pushes back against the workplace norm that extra shifts and self-sacrifice equal commitment, rejecting Fatima's implicit judgment.
rationales.benevolence: She stayed late to comfort a seven-year-old scared of his IV and held a mother's hand for three hours, giving fully to patients during her shift.

rationales.stimulation: She booked a weekend trip to Muscat with a resort and infinity pool, seeking a new travel experience in another country.
rationales.hedonism: The trip is centered entirely on pleasure — an infinity pool overlooking the Gulf — and she is counting down the days with excitement.
rationales.benevolence: She planned the trip with her close friend Sara, prioritizing shared enjoyment and quality time together.

rationales.self_direction: Layla told Sara that rest is 'doing something' and that enjoying the moment counts, asserting her own philosophy of how to spend time.
rationales.stimulation: She explored Muttrah fish market, haggled for dried limes, bought silver bangles at the old souk — immersing in new cultural experiences.
rationales.hedonism: They spent the afternoon doing nothing by the pool, ordered room service, and watched the sunset, fully embracing leisure without guilt.
rationales.achievement: When Sara expressed guilt about not 'doing more,' Layla actively argued against productivity-driven thinking, dismissing achievement metrics in favor of rest.
rationales.benevolence: She wanted Sara to internalize that rest matters, recognizing the same guilt pattern in her friend and trying to help her let go of it.

rationales.self_direction: Layla internally rejects the path her cousin Rania is taking — quitting her job because her fiance wants her to — and affirms that wanting different things does not make her broken.
rationales.conformity: She deliberately withholds her real opinions from the family WhatsApp, but internally refuses to accept the cultural expectation that she should want marriage and domesticity.
rationales.tradition: Her mother's comment that 'Rania is younger than you' drips with cultural expectation, and Layla rejects the traditional timeline of marriage and family-building.

rationales.self_direction: Layla defines her own metric for a well-lived life — good meals, sunsets, genuine laughter — rather than accepting the conventional measures Dr. Faris embodies.
rationales.hedonism: She explicitly contrasts her life of beach trips, restaurants, and travel against Dr. Faris's three years without a vacation, affirming pleasure as a legitimate life goal.
rationales.achievement: She wanted to ask Dr. Faris what the point of becoming a doctor was if he never enjoys being alive, explicitly questioning the value of professional achievement without enjoyment.
rationales.benevolence: She counts 'moments of genuine laughter with people I love' as her primary measure of a life well lived, centering close relationships.

rationales.self_direction: After losing a patient, Layla chose her own way of processing grief — going straight to the beach in her scrubs to sit with the waves until sunset.
rationales.hedonism: She sought the beach as a sensory and emotional refuge, letting the water and the sunset provide comfort after a devastating shift.
rationales.benevolence: She cared deeply for the eight-year-old patient, adjusting her pillows and bringing her extra apple juice, unable to prevent emotional attachment despite the professional risk.

rationales.self_direction: Layla told Nadia 'the work will always be there, the moments won't,' asserting her own philosophy about priorities and encouraging others to live by it.
rationales.hedonism: She describes a rooftop dinner in JBR with thirteen friends, sharing mezze and laughing so loud other tables looked over, fully immersed in the pleasure of the evening.
rationales.achievement: She explicitly countered Nadia's guilt about taking time off from work, dismissing the idea that professional productivity should override personal enjoyment.
rationales.benevolence: She persuaded Nadia not to cancel her own birthday dinner and told her the moments with loved ones matter more than work, actively caring for her friend's wellbeing.

rationales.self_direction: Layla's entire plan for her three days off is sleeping in and maybe a massage — she defines this as 'enough' on her own terms.
rationales.hedonism: She has zero plans beyond sleeping in and getting a massage, embracing pure rest and physical pleasure as a complete and satisfying use of her time.
rationales.achievement: She explicitly rejects any productive agenda for her time off, declaring 'that's the whole plan, that's enough.'

rationales.self_direction: When her aunt asked about settling down, Layla simply said she's happy with her life as it is, refusing to apologize or get defensive.
rationales.hedonism: She watched the sunset alone at the beach upon returning to Dubai, feeling full and describing herself as finally living the life she actually wants.
rationales.security: Her father's affirmation that she figured out something at thirty that took him fifty years gives her emotional grounding and stability in her choices.
rationales.conformity: She broke the expected script at the family gathering — her aunt had no response prepared for someone who wasn't apologizing or defending herself.
rationales.benevolence: Her father pulled her aside to say he's proud of her, and she felt the depth of that connection; the people who matter most are starting to see her life as she does.
